results.title: A Man and an organ
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Peter Johnson and John Bushelle
results.brief_description: A filmic insight into Ronald Sharp - the self-taught builder of the Grand Organ in the Sydney Opera House. No Australian building has caught the imagination of the world as much as the Sydney Opera House. Opened in 1973 by Her Majesty, Queen Elizabeth II, it was always intended that the main concert hall of this performing arts miracle building should have as its dominant, centre-stage focus a magnificent organ that would rival the splendour of the instrument in the Sydney Town Hall, the city’s biggest recital organ.

results.title: A Man's hands
results.brief_description: A witty and fast-cut montage dramatising the activities of the human hand: squeezing, poking, fixing, scratching, zipping, playing and touching. Alternatively funny and moving, entertaining and informative.

results.title: A Malecite fancy basket: national Indian arts and crafts
results.creator_credit: B T Film Sound and Geoff Noyce
results.brief_description: Veronica and Jim Atwin, Malecite Indians from the Kingsclear reserve, have been making functional baskets for many years. The film shows how they select and prepare the materials and then make a beautiful fancy basket from black ash and sweetgrass.

results.title: A Loving pinch = Cubit cubitan
results.creator_credit: Rapi Films, Sabirin Kasdani and Maman Firmansjah
results.brief_description: An example of a dangdut musical drama made popular in its time mostly by Indian filmmakers. The dangdut form of music/culture entertainment is a favourite amongst working-class Indonesians, mostly men who traditionally come from a hard day’s work to relax to the music and gyrating hips of the singers. The film features established dangdut star, Elvy Sukaesih, as a mother who comes to Jakarta with her two children to look for her husband, only to find he has eloped with another woman. Separated from her children when the place they are staying for the night catches fire, Elvy becomes a star by sheer luck and is later reunited with her children. While this has been going on her husband has lost his job and is thrown out of his own house by the other woman. Cast includes Elvy Sukaesih, Santi Sardi and Lukman Sardi. In Indonesian with English subtitles.

results.title: A Look outside (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Zero 16 Films, Gibson Film Productions and Dave Gibson
results.brief_description: An optional job experience scheme from 4th form at Nenae College helps students bridge the gap between the classroom and the world outside. Various students are shown gaining experience as a surveyor’s assistant, hairdresser, vet’s assistant and farm worker, working one day a week along side adults in these fields.

results.title: A Look inside
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Shows different aspects of work inside the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory. After a brief introduction to the importance of the livestock industry and the effects of disease, viewers are taken inside the laboratory to see some of the microbiological features.

results.title: A Look at parliament
results.creator_credit: State Film Centre of Victoria and R. Barrington-Scott
results.brief_description: Opening with the traditional swearing-in ceremony of the Governor of Victoria (Sir henry Winneke) this film briefly surveys the historic beginnings of the Victorian Parliament, including its architecture and design. From there it shows procedures relating to Victoria’s 46th Parliament. The work of the Governor, Legislative Assembly and Council, various committees and Officers of Parliament is viewed and there is a glimpse of the Parliamentary library.

results.title: A Long walk home
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, Jill Robb and Brian Bosisto
results.brief_description: The Flinders Ranges in South Australia are a remarkable chain of ranges and valleys penetrating the arid centre of Australia. The purity of its sunlight and colours is revealed in this study of the ranges and gorges and the flora and fauna of this ancient and fascinating region.
results.creator_credit_for_label: South Australian Film Corporation, Jill Robb and Brian Bosisto

results.title: A Long shot that paid off: CSIRO's atomic aborption project
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, S.T. Evans and Nicholas Alexander
results.brief_description: The discovery in the early 19th century that chemical elements could be identified by observing their emission spectra lead to the development of accurate methods of chemical analysis based on atomic emission spectra. But it was nearly 100 years before Dr A. Walsh of the CSIRO Division of Chemical Physics started asking questions and became convinced that there would be many fundamental advantages in using spectrochemical methods based on atomic absorption spectra. Despite many technical difficulties and lack of interest overseas, Dr Walsh and his colleagues persisted and finally showed that the technique they had devised, had widespread applications in fields as diverse as medicine, engineering, agriculture and mineral exploration. Cinematography: Peter Bruce

results.title: A Long night with lethal guests
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Geoffrey Barnes and Oliver Howes
results.brief_description: Deals with malaria in New Guinea and research to find a cure. The film travels with a medical anthropologist to the rain-forest clad Schrader mountains where the Hagahai people live. The Hagahai people are being treated for malaria and other related infections transmitted through contact with the malaria-rife coast due to new road and air links. Researchers are looking at the way immunity to malaria works while treating people like the Hagahai.
